Notes:

The file naming convention may look confusing, but:

  • The "A" series are just plain disk platters
  • The "B" series are dimpled platters like the photo without earrings
  • The "C" series are dimpled and have holes for earrings.

The "Alt" versions in "B" and "C" files just rotate the alternate platters. The image with earrings has the alternate "C" layout, the one with no earrings is the straight "B" series.

title: Doll High Chair [obsolete]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[UPDATE] 15-01-2018 I published an enforved version here

[UPDATE] 12-28-2016 I corrected the width of the slots for the leg enforcement and optimized the width of the part that holds the seat.

My daughter wanted a high chair for her doll. I designed a pretty simple construction which uses slot-in technology. It's press fit, so no wood glue is needed. I spray painted the backrest, the seat and the tray in red. The color fits perfect to the doll's jumpsuit.

My built was done from 6,5 mm baltic birch plywood on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute.

Torben adjusted the drawing to accommodate 9 mm material.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like this design.

Please be aware that the stl-file is for viewing purpose only. Don't print this design on a fdm-printer!

author: Astrofossil

description.text: To honor Epic Fu< (http://www.epicfu.com/) visiting CrashSpace (http://crashspace.pbworks.com/) March 2010, Sean asked me to create a 3d version of their logo for the Makerbot. This is the result, along with several of the files I used in the process to create the STL. First I used Preview (OSX) to convert an EPS version of the logo to PNG. Then I used GIMP to clean it up and created two pngs - the base (rect) and letters. I imported these into Inkscape individually and used the Path-trace bitmap tool to create paths, and saved as SVG. Then I imported these into Blender, scaled, extruded, positioned, and converted to mesh. Then I appended the base/rect mesh to the letters mesh and converted to STL. The Inkscape-Blender part is actually more complex. I found it necessary to use Inkscape Path-break apart, and some other cleanups to make it work. Also Blender didnt like loading multiple svg, so I had to quit and restart it for each model. I have not yet successfully printed the object, as my bot keeps having feed problems. I'm sharing files to date so others can try. I also wrote up a bit more how-to over on http://wiki.makerbot.com/making-a-3d-logo

description.text:
If your like me, and don't like to carry an actual wallet with you, this might help your cards last longer. The nice feature of this is that it can stack cards in different height, so it's easier to see the cards, and get the one you want.

Just push your cards in place and they are secured. When you want to use them, push them all up with your thumb, and then release. Cards should now be nicely stacked so that you can select the one you want. Once your ready, just push them back.

Please report any issues with it. I noticed that an old, slightly bend card, with high emboss, did not work as a first card, since the embossed text could prevent the card from dropping in place.

Here is a Tile version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068719

Since this is a part that you keep in your hand, sand it. Bear minimum is to sand the groove edge, since your pushing agenst it with your thumb.
I saw a commerical of a card holder and started to think how does it stack those cards so nicely. Once I got how it might work, I made a couple of prototypes and found the most compact form.

This is a charge port release lever for the Nissan LEAF electric car model years 2011-2012. The original lever is very fragile and you could easily hit it with your shoe and break it. It also breaks easily when used in below freezing weather. A new one costs (in Finland) 120€ and comes with the complete assy including the cables and metal parts and the hood release lever as well. Far from ecologic.

THIS IS FOR A LEFT-HAND DRIVE CAR, for RHD remember to mirror along the width of the part before printing to ensure it'll fit in your car! Thanks @JohnVidler

I printed one in PLA in February 2016. Now, in August 2017 it's still working perfectly and is way less fragile and less sensitive to cold compared to the original one.

1. Cut the small support from where the cable goes in the printed part.
  2. Remove the lever assy from car (disconnect cables from levers)
  3. With pliers squeeze the end of the metal rod that locks the levers in place, pull it out.
  4. Replace the charge port lever with the printed one and put the rod back.
  5. Make sure the lever springs are correctly installed.
  6. With pliers, or a screwdriver and mallet widen the end of the metal rod so it stays in place again.
  7. Reinstall to car.

title: Maxmicron dual extruder fan shrouds single and 2 x 30mm fans

description.text:
This is a mod for the MaxMicron Dual extruder fan. I didn't like just one 40mm fan cooling both of the E3D hot ends so I made this one which requires 2 30mm fans. The holes in the bottom are for a filament cooler that I am working on next.
I made the mounting ears thick with a tight fit so if yours is a little wider you can use a Dremel to thin it out and fit properly. I have also made the holes 3.5mm for 4mm screws so that the screws will make threads and I don't have to use nuts on the back.
I have also modified the dual fan to use the one fan that came with the kit.
If anyone would like me to modify any part of this just leave a comment.
This is my first time uploading so I hope this will be of help for the community.

print_settings.Notes:: The stands should be printed laying on their sides to ensure the weakness of layers is not in the Z-axis. Supports are needed in this case so that the two rods that hold the controllers can be printed.

description.text:
Stand for 4 Xbox Controllers

The model consists of 4 parts:

  • Controller stand
  • Base
  • Batteries Holder
  • Handle

Controller stand
There are 3 versions of the controller stand included. They all fit in the model but Version 3 is the best one as prints showed.

Base
With good quality of printing the base can hold the 4 stands together. Mind that controllers are heavy so the base itself won't do the trick so you can lift the thing off the table. Screwing is needed for this to be possible.

Batteries Holder
The batteries holder has an important role in the model. Using a nut and a bolt to attach it to the Base you can make the thing solid and not be afraid to lift it off the table.

Handle
Since the Base and the Batteries Holder keep the Stands together, why not have a handle?

Supports:

Yes

Notes:
  • The stands should be printed laying on their sides to ensure the weakness of layers is not in the Z-axis. Supports are needed in this case so that the two rods that hold the controllers can be printed.
  • The Base and the Batteries Holder should be printed standing. The Batteries Holder will need supports because of the holes for the handle.
  • The Handle should be printed laying on its side, again, to ensure stability in the right directions.

Starting from the idea that I need to fit 4 controllers I looked for ready things. I really liked Clem_golgoth's design to start with. I knew I need to print 4 of these and get them connected somehow in the middle. There already is an idea with a remix of his work but it is hard to print and ... actually does not look as cool as what I had in mind. So I needed to add some way to attach them all to some plate at the bottom and align 4 of them in 4 directions. I got a print of the first design. The controller was not stable enough. It used the same angle Clem_golgoth's original uses. So I needed to modify the angle and make the controller lean back a bit more. This lead to the need of more length in the bottom part. Since I wanted the stand to be non-plastic-expensive I added some holes in the middle. That made it hard to print. In fact, because it was not well stuck to the bed it broke while printing. This lead to the complete redesign of the middle part and I am pretty happy with the third version.

When the controller stands were ready a plate was needed to merge them. And one on top to make sure they stay together. The one on top also has a holder for 5 batteries - just to use the space. Then I added a handle. I was not sure it will actually "work" well or it will break, but after I had all the things printed and assembled I am pretty happy with the final result.

This is ice scraper part I modeled to replace the broken one in my favorite design Snow and ice scraper and brush tool.
https://patents.google.com/patent/USD422146S/en

The term of this design is expired in 2014. So I just give a reference to the source of this excellent tool.

This work is in progress, since anyone else would require a handle for this part, but it is not modelled yet.

12/16/2016 - updated connection side sizes to better match the original one.

Printer:

JGAURORA Z - 605S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Layer 0.1 mm Nozzle 0.4 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

ABS (or some similar hit resistant plastic) shall be used to survive against ice.
Bad warping is experienced during print, so any measures to prevent warping shall be used, so raft must be used. Also I added model with additional brim of 0.4mm height to improve adhesion.
Support is required on a small area near forward blade.
Use high temperature for ABS (no fan) to avoid delamination during use. I set 255 C, but I'm not sure how temperature sensor is calibrated.
Note higher temperature makes warping of ABS worse.
It took many hours to reproduce original design. There are still some simplifications and tricks to improve printability and durability of this part.

description.text: A puzzle ring: its designed to be printed in four separate parts, in four separate colours, each a little ring with tabs that click into each other. The tabs are positioned so there is a unique way of arranging the pieces (like a puzzle). It's not that hard to solve or anything. I made it in OpenSCAD. It's pretty much just a series of cylinders with holes, and the tabs are just rectangular pegs and cutouts.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2mm

It's designed in OpenSCAD: script file included for modification, if desired. I tried a few different sizes, and liked the settings in the script. You can modify "ring_inner_diam" for a bigger or smaller finger and "ring_height" and/or "ring_thick" to change the chunkiness of the parts.

print_settings.Notes:: Try to make the part as strong as possible!

author: Bub11

description.text:
If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Update I am now building these and selling the latest version on my Etsy! So if you don't have a printer yet, I will be happy to print you one! Check it out at https://www.etsy.com/listing/109657227/ Now you can battle your chess two ways. Traditionally on a chess board or combine your powers to form the ultimate chess fighting robot. Had this idea a while ago and this contest gave me the perfect opportunity to make it happen. Having to use Tinkercad to make it happen was wonderfully educational too. It's a limited tool in many way and the limitations were in their own way liberating. TinkerCad Files:
Scaled: https://tinkercad.com/things/dm5lLLYUl1q
Original Size: https://tinkercad.com/things/beTFmjGvzMu EDIT: Updated STLs with new versions to fix printing problems in original versions. Now on v1.2. Old plate renamed "V1" for historical purposes. EDIT2: Discovered that some of my pieces, most notably the knight, exceeded the dimensions stipulated in the contest rules. Added a scaled down plate that fits the contest requrements. Called it "1.2 small". Individual pieces are still the larger size. EDIT3: 1.3 small added that thickens the connections to the pawns and removes the tabs connecting them. 1.2 (big) not tested yet, I have no reason to believe it won't work as is so I'm leaving it. EDIT4: Taking this off WIP status becauase any future work will be in version 2.X. (See deritives)

I tried to design it to print supportless, but there are a few places I might have missed.
  • Print a plate for each side or print the individual pieces the number of times specified.
  • Play chess or...
  • Slide the tab from the queen into the notch on the king and slide downards to lock the body together.
  • Take the 2 type A pawns and slide into the shoulder slots.
  • Take 4 type B pawns and lock their feet together to form 2 legs.
  • Flip the knights over for feet and snap the legs into them.
  • Snap the legs into the body.
  • Take the remaing 2 type B pawns and lock their feet into the feet of the rooks to form two upper arms.
  • Snap the shoulders pawns into the upper arms.
  • Snap the upper arm pawns into the bishops to form the hands.

comments.text:
I printed about half of the 1.2 small plate. The pawns are fragile at this size, their heads break off. The King
&
amp; Queen mate, but don't won't slide. I also think there is a piece of plastic at the bottom of the king that will prevent the pieces from sliding flush together. The alterations to the knight are worth it, it prints well. I'm not sure the tiny tabs you've added on the pawns are productive - they don't print distinctly, and make it more difficult to press the pieces together. I'd drop the nose off the face entirely, or make it thicker, it's just too fine to print well at this size. Looking forward to 1.3!

comments.text:
A couple of major things, a couple minor things. The bad news first - check out the king
&
amp; queen slide, you've miscalculated, there's not enough room to drop them together before sliding them to fit. The knight prints pretty messy, including a fully dropped loop in my print. The tabs on the knight break off when the pawn is inserted on this piece, but they fit beautifully everywhere else. I have two theories: 1) the print hasn't recovered from the overhang, so the adhesion is bad or 2) the thinner tabs on your other pieces flex slightly when the pawn is inserted, but the tabs on the knights are too thick, so they break off instead. Higher fill density might also fix this. I printed some pieces at 0% fill, some with 10%, with 2 shells.

title: Anet A8 extruder mounted filament guide

description.text:
Extruder-mounted filament guide for Anet A8. I made it after mounting cable chain, because the filament was sometimes interfering with the cable chain. This filament guide prevents that problem.

For printing I used:
PLA with 185 / 60 hot end / heated bed temperatures
50% infill (although 100% will look cleaner)

comments.text: Thanks for this.  I had the same issue after installing my chain and while it didn't hurt the function it was annoying to no end.  This thing worked beautifully.

support required

print_settings.Notes:: print in flexible material at whatever size you want.

description.text:
Anti-vibration pads for things-that-make-noise.

Designed to reduce vibrations traveling from things, into the surface they are on.

Print with some flexible filament like filaflex etc. use double sided tape to fix to device, triangles pointing down. 2mm triangle width and 4mm height are a good starting point. Try different geometries if you want.

You can use the customizer to make them in the size you need, or change the geometry in the advanced tab.
The width is rounded down to fit the triangles on the surface, meaning if you put triangle base width at 2mm ,extrusion width (flat top) at 0.4mm, and overall width at 50x50mm, your resulting pad will be 50x48mm, because 2+0.4 = 2.4 and 50 / 2.4 = 20.8. So the surface will be rounded down to fit 20 triangles -> 2.4 x 20 = 48

(sorry for the photos, mt camera is unable to shoot black rubber)

Printer:

Original Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

-

Infill:

-

Notes:

print in flexible material at whatever size you want.
made in openSCAD

comments.text: It does for me, I printed it in recreus filaflex, and the printer is more quiet than without, but I have no comparison to other dampening designs.
comments.author: cakes

description.text: Did a wire container ring a while back and was amazed at how many people liked and downloaded it. I did several for myself on a Mega Kossel I'm building but found that when there are just a few wires I would much rather tuck them down into the slots of the extrusion and just trap them there. I recalled a similar design here but could not find it, so I did this one from memory. My apologies to the original designer for not giving proper credit. If I could find it I would certainly do that. I have two models. The first with a turning tab to twist it easier. It takes a lot more material to build and I prefer the smaller one anyway. I am posting this without having made one yet so I hope it fits your 20/20 extrusion ok. EDIT: I have made them now and they work great in 2020 extrusions.
A 3D model of the Denver International Airport!

For some reason the PCR800 rain gauge is designed to be mounted on a flat surface, and this has always bugged me. Surely it should mount on a pole!

Specifically it should be mounted on a piece of 20mm plastic conduit, or 25mm aluminum tube.

So I made this adapter to fit your PCR800 (Oregon Scientific Rain Gauge) onto a vertical pole. There are two parts, the adapter to the PCR800, and a mount for the bottom, which has a hole in it so the measured water runs straight out.

One side benefit of this mount is that by enclosing the base of the rain gauge it reduces the likelihood of bug/spider infestation. It is also easier to get down when you need to change the batteries.

I've used OpenSCAD so folk can adapt and adjust to get the result they want, and provided pre-made STLs for poles of 20mm and 25mm diameter. I printed mine in ASA (Acrylonitrile Styrene Acrylate) for maximum durability, but ABS will probably do.

There is a small amount of support to remove, in the areas where the PCR800 feet are bolted on. I used 10mm M3 stainless steel bolts. If the fit on the pole is not tight (like mine) just drill a small hole and insert a small screw to stop anything blowing away!

The photos should show how it goes together.

One consideration when printing is that you need to have a warm / hot build surface and environment to stop warping, but as the print gets near the top part of the cone you may want more ventilation, as the plastic may not harden enough between layers (and there will be some 'slumping').

LED board made in the shape of a meteor. LED colors designed to match an actual meteor's colors. Inspiration: http://kingofwallpapers.com/meteor/meteor-004.jpg

Meteor Theme Our assignment in this project was to create an LED board in Solidworks. We had to create appropriately sized holes for LED lights, walls to fit in hot glue (to carry the light better), and grooves on the bottom side to hold resistors and overall wiring (including positive/negative nodes). We chose the meteor theme and created a matching LED board with matching lights.

LED Circuit Board Constraints: Had to be powered by a 9V source; at least 3 branches with separate LEDs requiring separate energy/current amounts; required use of resistors to optimize LED performance; required detailed plans for each step (calculations on how much energy/current each LED would receive, plans for wiring set-up).

author: MrKindergarten

print_settings.Notes:: Print with the flat side on the print bed, shape facing away.

description.text:
This is a remix of the snowman maker by CloudJ. Instead of a snowman this produces a replica of an ice cream cone, in snow (thus snow cone :). I usually scale this to 50%.

I was amazed at how well the original concept by CloudJ was able to produce objects in snow so I wanted to try an object which had some finer details to see how it would fair. In addition to a different object being produced I made some other changes to improve on the original concept. Instead of using pegs and peg holes I use spheres and sphere indentations which increases the durability of the print and also prevents snow from clogging the peg holes. By using a symmetrical design instead of the original which had two distinct parts this design uses a single piece which is printed twice. By keeping the mold open in the bottom you are able to pack snow into the closed mold producing a stronger object.

Printer:

Migbot Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with the flat side on the print bed, shape facing away.

description.text:
Just took the file, ran it through online stl repair and split it up in openscad.
I've included the openscad file in case you would like to split your own files.
Make sure the file you are splitting is in the same folder as the openscad file.

You can use 'intersection' instead of difference to get the other part

Reasons why I need to split it? It didn't easily fit onto my print bed, and also if on fails you dont mess up the other.

print_settings.Notes:: Four top layers, four bottom layers (makes for a sturdy tin). Three perimeters ensures the print is solid (no infill happens at all). You can set infill to 100% if you wish, but that shouldn't make any difference.

description.text:
This Christmas container uses layering to produce a four-colour snowman tin using no special equipment and no mid-job filament changes. Here's how to print the white tin pictured. I strongly suggest you read all of this before printing. It's straightforward, but unusual!

I strongly suggest a layer height of 0.2mm, as that is what the layers are set up for. If you find that your slicer preview doesn't show the rectangular border around BlackST.stl, GreenST.stl etc. then lower your extrusion width slightly so that it fits comfortably within the border's 0.5mm width.

To print a white tin:

Print BlackST.stl in black, with a one-perimeter brim. Leave it on the print bed.
Print GreenST.stl in green with a one perimeter brim. Leave it on the print bed.
Print RedST.stl in red with a one perimeter brim. Leave it on the print bed.
Print WhiteSTLid.stl in white with your usual skirt or whatever (i.e. as you usually print).

Remove the completed lid from the bed and then print Print Box.stl in white in your usual way.

To print a red box, print [the three other colours]ST.stl, followed by RedSTLid.stl, all layered on top of each other, then Box.stl in red.
To print a green box, print [the three other colours]ST.stl, followed by GreenSTLid.stl, all layered on top of each other, then Box.stl in green.
To print a black box, print [the three other colours]ST.stl, followed by BlackSTLid.stl, all layered on top of each other, then Box.stl in black.

Enjoy!

Why are the layered prints printed with a one-perimeter brim? Because I've added a one-layer box around each of the layered prints, so that when your slicer centres the job, that doesn't mess up the alignment, but the slicer won't necessarily start with that outer box -- and it needs to, to ensure the filament is flowing properly before the 'colouring in' begins. Having a small brim switched on ensures that the slicer starts with the outside of the job.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm highly recommended

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

Four top layers, four bottom layers (makes for a sturdy tin). Three perimeters ensures the print is solid (no infill happens at all). You can set infill to 100% if you wish, but that shouldn't make any difference.

description.text:
The Boss Monster promo pack comes with a new set of cards, some of which have variable damage intended to be randomised via a dice roll. However the promo pack does not include a die with it.

Rather than use a plain old boring die, I thought it would be more fun to use something more thematic and fitting for the game. Modelled after the damage indicator symbols found on room cards.

When I have printed a die, I will upload images.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

Low density

Notes:

Printed with PLA

After printing I did the following:

  • Filed it down after removing it from the raft
  • Cleared up some loose "threads" from the three
  • Primed it black, painted it white, and sealed it with a matte varnish.
Post filing. The finished result. I'm not as good a painter as I remember, but thankfully the choppy white lines help add to the 8-bit effect. At least, I like to think that. :p

author: adrijimenez13

description.text:
Overview

This thing presents Scalar S 3D printer.

Scalar Family 3D printers are "scalable" printers.

This version is a basic version of the original Scalar XL model ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409 ), using 2020 extrusion profile with a 20x20x20cm build volume.

Reviewing the idea of a reprap printer, a printer that can auto replicate and scale, we wanted to propose a 3D printer with plastic parts for you to print, and with a way to "scale" easily.

Key Features

  • Simple design based on standard 2020 extrusion profiles
  • All axis are rolling over VSlot extrusion profiles. All Smooth rods have been removed removed
  • More secure with our new SSR cover system modified for 2020 ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912871)
  • Evolutive Design : More upgrades are to come!
  • Lightweight and strong frame
  • Smooth and Silent: using VSlots and V Wheels for X and Y axis

Assembly instructions

Assembly instructions can be found on our website documentation page (in french for now, but can easily be understood by english speeking folk:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/assembly-instructions-for-scalar-3d-printer/notice-de-montage-de-scalar-s/

Updates

  • 2018.03.05 - Update BasicHolderFor2020V3 and 2020_X_Idler_TensionerV5 (stronger)
  • 2017.12.20 - Add X axis end stop for M2.5x8mm screws (2020_X_EndStop_Holder_screw.stl)
  • 2017.08.16 - Re-inforced X axis Idler tensioner
  • 2017.01.31: Update all parts that were improved.
  • 2016.12.28: removed wrong models and added missing ones
  • 2016.12.16 : Original release

Remixed

This thing is a remix from our original version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409
Many of you liked it.
The main idea remains, but we adjusted the overall size to something more standard, and we reviewed/remodelled all the plastic parts to:

  • Have a lighter design
  • Less parts
  • Reduce noise
  • Increase Z axis Accuracy
  • Increase X axis smooth motion
  • Upgrade heat bed motion system
  • Designed a box for the electronics
  • remove Belt tensioner
  • Add spool holder based on extrusion profiles
  • Using a 120W PSU
  • Using a 250W 220V heatbed that doesn't require big power supplies.

Printer presentation

https://youtu.be/puIoTEjJvgA

Accessories

Tools

Hot end holders

  • AllInOne Hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:967021
  • AluHotEnd V6/V7 holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962920
  • Prometheus V1.1 hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962664
  • E3D V6 / E3D lite6 Hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962622

Upgrades from Scalar Owners

  • (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/perryscope63) for his Donut shape fanshroud : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1499102

Upgrades

Spool

Electronic

  • Electronic (Arduino+Ramps+LCD2004) box: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945299

Tools/Accessories:

Firmware

The procedure to install the firmware on Scalar 3D printer is available on our documentation page:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/updatingupgrading-your-3d-printer-firmware/

You will also find the newest firmware available to download directly on the page.
Special thanks to Marlin Community for providing this great firmware and evolutions.

Misc

  • Calibration set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:909829

Where to buy

http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/3d-printers/222-scalar-s-3d-printer-20x20x20-cm.html

Characteristics

Mainly all technical information can be found on our website:
http://3dmodularsystems.com

But here is a summary of the main characteristics :

Scalar S Premium

  • Standard build platform: 200x200mm heat-bed
  • 220V 250w silicon heat-bed with a 3mm aluminium print surface
  • Compatible with well known hot ends (E3D, E3D Lite6, Hexagone, ...), 3mm and 1.75mm
  • Built-in blower fan
  • Built-in LCD and SD card support
  • Built-in spool holder
  • 120W 12V stand alone power supply block
  • Inductive probe for bed levelling
  • Plastic parts available for different hot ends: E3D, E3D lite6, AluHotEnd and Prometheus V1.1.
  • Modular Design

Scalability

Because you guys have different ways of life, events happening and so on, we wanted to make sure that those printers can be scaled by only adding the necessary parts to upgrade/downgrade your printers.
This way whenever you want the printer to be bigger then we have a kit for that.
The Scalar S has just been released so future upgrades are to come.

BOM

Available on our documentation page http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/assembly-instructions-for-scalar-3d-printer/notice-de-montage-de-scalar-s/

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

Where better to hang up the sword for a day or two, pull up a flagon of mead or ten, and celebrate Yule, the winter solstice, Modraniht or any other end-of-year pagan festivity, than the village long house, and at the Thegn's expense? This building represents a traditional Longhouse of the Anglo-Saxon era at the time of the Viking invasions / the reign of Alfred the Great. Please note that the two roof sections are quite thin and the tile rows are zillionths ( OK slight exaggeration but they're close) of an inch above the next so you may have to set your layer width etc to as fine as you can get.
I've included a roof truss in the package but mine actually came together fine without any as long as the top roof edges are butted up squarely against each other and glued

author: djmolo

description.text:
Overview

This thing presents Scalar L 3D printer.

Scalar Family 3D printers are "scalable" printers.

This version is a fully upgraded version of the original Scalar XL model ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409 )

Reviewing the idea of a reprap printer, a printer that can auto replicate and scale, we wanted to propose a 3D printer with plastic parts for you to print, and with a way to "scale" easily.

Key Features

  • More stability and Accuracy with
    Bed with Dual drive system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1766326 )
    Z Axis based on Strong Jaw System ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912785 )
  • Possible upgrade to Helix drive system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912399 )
  • More secure with our new SSR cover system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912871)
  • Evolutive Design : More upgrades are to come!
  • Most upgrades are compatible with both Scalar XL premium and Scalar L.
  • Strong with 3030 aluminium extrusion
  • Smooth and Silent: using VSlots and V Wheels for X and Y axis

Assembly instructions

Assembly instructions can be found on our website documentation page:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/scalar-lxl-premium-assembly-manual/

Updates

  • 2018.03.05 - Update BasicHolderFor2020V3 and 2020_X_Idler_TensionerV5 (stronger)
  • 2017.12.20 - Added X axis en stop holders (1 model with cable tie:2020_X_EndStop_Holder.stl, 1 model for M2.5x8mm screws:2020_X_EndStop_Holder_screw.stl)
  • 2017.08.16 : Re-inforced X Axis Idler tnsioner
  • 2017.08.03 : Update list of upgrade links
  • 2017.06.30 : Fix X Carriage
  • 2016.12.01 : Original release

Remixed

This thing is a remix from our original version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409
Many of you liked it.
The main idea remains, but we adjusted the overall size to something more standard, and we reviewed/remodelled all the plastic parts to:

  • Have a better design
  • Have stronger parts.
  • Reduce noise
  • Increase Z axis Accuracy
  • Increase X axis smooth motion
  • Upgrade heat bed motion system
  • Designed a box for the electronics
  • Remove Belt tensioner
  • Stronger Spool Holder

Printer presentation

https://youtu.be/UDSlrKqSYuA

Accessories

Tools

  • Air Spray Holder ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402747)
  • PS_On box ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193481)
  • Filament runout system (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2102582)

Hot end holders

  • AllInOne Hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:967021
  • AluHotEnd V6/V7 holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962920
  • Prometheus V1.1 hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962664
  • E3D V6 Hot end holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962622
  • Tennis ball vibration dampers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1209709

Upgrades from Scalar Owners

  • (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/wubwub89) T Slot M3 ultra low profile vibration damper adapter : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1498204
  • (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/perryscope63) for his Donut shape fanshroud : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1499102
    • (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/wubwub89) FilaPulley (Filament Support Pulley & arm) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517515

Upgrades

  • Helix Drive system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912399 )
  • Titan extruder Holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982014)
  • another version of Titan extruder mount systeml (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2226476)
  • BLTouch holder for Titan extruder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275021)
  • BLTouch Holder for standard hotend holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2135730)
  • Power supply holder for Re-enforcement upgrade (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2466825)
  • MKS TFT 2.8 touch screen box upgrade for standard Scalar electronic box (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2196704)
  • V3.0 of the electronic box (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402773) => Arduino 2560 / Re-Arm + Ramps 1.4 + LCD2004/GLCD + Rapsberry p 2/3

Spool

  • Scalar - UFO Spool Holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1227324

Electronic

  • Electronic (Arduino+Ramps+LCD2004) box: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945299
  • Scalar - Ramps 1.4 Box / Case Lite : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242105
  • 200W PSU cover box: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1544041

Tools/Accessories

  • Pensil Sharpener holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951057
  • Extrusion Profile Cable ties Clips: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943975
  • Extrusion profiles Joints: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951092
  • Vibration/Sound Damper feet: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:954905
  • Scalar - UFO Spool Holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1227324

Firmware

The procedure to install the firmware on Scalar 3D printer is available on our documentation page:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/updatingupgrading-your-3d-printer-firmware/

You will also find the newest firmware available to download directly on the page.
Special thanks to Marlin Community for providing this great firmware and evolutions.

Misc

  • Calibration set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:909829

Where to buy

http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/3d-printers/221-scalar-l-3d-printer-30x30x30-cm.html

Characteristics

Mainly all technical information can be found on our website:
http://3dmodularsystems.com

But here is a summary of the main characteristics

Scalar L Premium

  • Large build platform: 300x300mm heat-bed
  • 220V 600w silicon heat-bed with a 3mm aluminium print surface
  • Compatible with well known hot ends (E3D, Hexagone, ...), 3mm and 1.75mm
  • Built-in blower fan
  • Built-in LCD and SD card support
  • Built-in spool holder
  • 200W 12V industrial power supply
  • Inductive probe for bed levelling
  • Plastic parts available for different hot ends: E3D, AluHotEnd and Prometheus V1.1.
  • Modular Design

Scalability

Because you guys have different ways of life, events happening and so on, we wanted to make sure that those printers can be scaled by only adding the necessary parts to upgrade/downgrade your printers.
This way whenever you want the printer to be bigger then we have a kit for that:
We already made several Upgrade kits for our previous Scalar XL model and we plan to keep the "Scalable" / Evolutivity concept for this model! So be prepare, there is plenty of cool stuff to come.

BOM

Available on our documentation page http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/scalar-lxl-premium-assembly-manual/

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

author: diekl99

description.text: This is a solid works generated model of the Oklahoma state football logo. This is a very simple model as it consists of a couple extrusions and a couple sketches. It is very basic yet creative. We had decided to cut out some of the smaller details because we thought it wasn't required. The model was created between the constraints: 10 by 10 by 10 cm. The hardest part of the model was extruding the different levels. We started the project by conducting research, searching the internet for logos/ pictures to model. After finding our logo, we drew blue prints. We then began using solidworks to construct this model, it took a week or two. Overall, this was a very enjoyable project and I had fun creating it.

Both me and partner being fans of college football wanted to pursue of a project on creating a logo of one of the college teams. We decided to use this state because we found this team logo to be intresting.

Project #3: 3-2d Art With a partner, you will design a “2D” placard using Solidworks. You and your partner will have the same design which meets the constraints below, and you will EACH use Solidworks to create your design. Click here to browse for inspiration: http://www.thingiverse.com/explore/popular/art/2d-art/page:1 Constraints: Should have a flat back; detail will be on the front side
Should fit inside a box that is 10 cm x 10 cm when lying flat
Should be no more than 1 cm thick
Should be as detailed as possible
Detail will be made using sketches that are extruded to different heights
No error messages
Do not extrude contours - each feature should have its own sketch
Part should be CENTERED about the origin
Demonstrate efficient use of construction lines
Demonstrate efficient use of automatic and manual relations
Demonstrate efficient use of Smart Dimensions
Demonstrate efficient use of mirroring
Demonstrate efficient use of linear or circular patterns
